resources.string: I have read and I accept these conditions

Help us in the fight against Dengue, Chickungunya, Yellow Fever, and Zika! Notify the presence of tiger mosquitoes (Aedes albopictus), yellow fever mosquitoes (Aedes aegypti), and their breeding sites.

You can find more information at www.mosquitoalert.com

Thanks for your interest and participation,

The Mosquito Alert Team

string-array.name: gallery_array
string-array.item: The main difference between the yellow fever mosquito (left) and the tiger mosquito (right), is right after its head, in the thorax: The yellow fever mosquito has 4 white lines with a lyre-shaped pattern, while the tiger mosquito has a single white line. Foto: Vincent Robert (CC BY 2.0)

Tiger mosquito (Aedes albopictus). Its main characteristic is its black body with white lines and spots. Note the white line on the head and thorax. This female has the abdomen full of blood. Photo: Roger Eritja (©)

Yellow fever mosquito (Aedes aegypti). Recognized by its dark brown color with white lines and spots. Right above its head, in the thorax, it has 4 white lines with a lyre-shaped pattern. Photo: James Gathany (ECDC, domini públic)
Tiger mosquito Ae. albopictus: Observe the black color that characterizes Ae. albopictus. Photo: Roger Eritja (©)
Yellow fever mosquito Ae. aegypti: Observe the brown color that characterizes Ae. aegypti. Foto: Mark Yokoyama (CC BY 2.0)
Who bites? Only female mosquitoes, and in this case females of tiger mosquito that usually bite during the day. Photo: Roger Eritja (©)
Two female yellow fever mosquitoes. Photo: Roger Eritja (©)\n
Tiger mosquito male (left) and female (right). The males have plumes on their heads. Photo: Roger Eritja (©)\n

Aedes eggs. The eggs are so small they are almost invisible to the naked eye. Female tiger and yellow fever mosquitoes lay eggs on the dry walls of small vessels near stagnant water. Photo: Roger Eritja (©)
Aedes mosquito larvae (longer) and pupae (rounder). The larvae are aquatic and they eventually turn into pupae to finally become adult mosquitoes. Photo: Roger Eritja (©)
Aedes larvae (longer) and pupae (rounder) in the water. Photo: Roger Eritja (©)
Adult tiger mosquitoes emerge from pupae into the air. This process is known as metamorphosis. Photo: Roger Eritja (©)

resources.string: Before submitting this mosquito report, please:
- attach a photo of the breeding site

This is the demo version of Mosquito Alert. With this version you cannot share data. If you want to participate in the project by contributing data, please click OK to install the full Mosquito Alert application. (If you already have the full version, you can uninstall the demo at any time.)
Use current location or select location from map?
Are you sure you want to delete this report?
This report has not been saved. Are you sure you want to exit?
No internet connection.\n\nTo view the feed, please connect to the internet and select \'refresh\' from the menu.
You have already completed this mission. Thank you!
Synchronize data with the Mosquito Alert server to receive new missions and the latest Mosquito Alert news.
Internet connection failure, transmission error. Your data will be synchronized later automatically.
No internet connection. Your data will be synchronized automatically when there is a connection available.
Report deleted from phone but there was a transmission error. Your data will be synchronized later automatically.
Report deleted from phone but there is no internet connection. Your data will be synchronized automatically when there is a connection available.
Your locatioin cannot be detected because GPS and network receivers are both off. Please activate them or choose a location on the map.
Your location has not yet been detected. Please wait a few more seconds and try again or else select location from map..
Transmission error. Your data has been saved on the device and will be sent later. Thank you!
No internet connection. Your report will be sent automatically when there is a connection available. Thank you!
If you want, you can write a message here for the research team. For example, you can describe the mosquito in more detail. Don\'t add personal information.
Button for sending report to research center
SD card not available – data cannot be saved.
C/ d\'accés a la Cala St. Francesc, 14
Your GPS and network receivers are off so it Is not possible to detect your location. Activate them now?
If you select OK, your report will be sent to the project team and parts of it will be published on the public web map at www.mosquitoalert.com.
Report sent. Thank you! Remember to check the project website for more information.
Will you send your mosquito by post to the lab?
The photographs in Mosquito Alert were provided by R. Eritja (www.eritja.com).
Copyright © 2013, 2014 John R.B. Palmer, Aitana Oltra, Joan Garriga and Frederic Bartumeus\n\u0020\u0020\u0020\u0020
1. How does the breeding site look?
1. What does your mosquito look like?
No, it\'s another type of breeding site
Turn on the Location of your device to let Mosquito Alert determine your position
Do you see a mosquito in this photo?
So tell us if you see a mosquito.
We are looking for tiger mosquitoes or yellow fever mosquitoes, but other species can also get in.
On the next screen we explain how to recognize them.
It is small (<1 cm), black, with horizontal white lines on the abodmen.
It has a vertical white line just after the head, in the thorax.
It is small (<1 cm), blackish brown and has horizontal white and wide lines on the abdomen. On each side of these lines there are round white spots.
It has a lyre-shaped pattern just after the head, in the thorax.
The most recognisable part of the mosquito is the torax drawing. Do you recognise the drawing in the picture?
Touch the picture to enlarge it.
This scoring considers your activity using the app and the quality of your sent photos.

HELP:
If you have found a mosquito, follow these steps:

  • Step 1 - What does your mosquito look like?: answer the four questions to tell us more about the mosquito you've found

  • Step 2 - Where did you find the mosquito?: select "Current" if you found the mosquito in the place where you are right now. In this case, the app detects your current location. Activate the GPS on your phone if you want the location to be more accurate. If you have seen a mosquito elsewhere and you've made a photo and have saved it, select "Elsewhere" and place it on the map.

  • Step 3 - Add a photo : take a picture with the camera of the phone or attach it if you have it saved. To make a good photo, grab the mosquito by its legs and try to take one picture from the front and one from the side.

  • Step 4 - Do you want to add any comments?: you can give more details about your finding. Please do not add personal information.

You can view and edit your findings in "MY MAP". The data you submit is posted on the map www.mosquitoalert.com.
Black with white lines on the body and the legs

HELP:
If you've found a potential breeding site, especially a sewer or drain on a public space containing stagnant water, follow these steps:

  • Step 1 - How does it look? : answer the four questions to know more about the breeding site.

  • Step 2 - Where did you find it?: select "Current" if you're in front of a breeding site. In this case the app detects your current location. Activate the GPS on your phone if you want the location of your finding to be more accurate. If you have seen a breeding site elsewhere and have already saved a picture, select "Elsewhere" and place it on the map.

  • Step 3 - Add a photo : Take a picture with the camera of your phone or attach it if you have it already saved. If there is stagnant water and/or larvae, try to make them visible in the photo.

  • Step 4 - Do you want to add any comments?: you can give more details about your finding. Please do not add personal information.

You can view and edit your findings in "MY MAP". The data you submit is posted on the map www.mosquitoalert.com.
Brown with white lines on the body and the legs\\n
No, it has 4 in a lyre-shaped pattern
What does the abdomen of your mosquito look like? Check the (i) button and select an answer:
With white lines and thin white spots
With white lines and thick white spots
What color is your mosquito? Check the (i) button and select an answer:
Look right after the head, at the thorax. Does it have a single white line? Check the (i) button and select an answer:
Before submitting this breeding site report, please:
Use this space to include a note or comments if necessary. Don\'t add personal information.

The tiger mosquito and the yellow fever mosquito are small and dark with white spots. The tiger mosquito is black, while the yellow fever mosquito is dark brown.

\\n

Illustrations: J.Luis Ordóñez, CREAF (CC-BY-NC 3.0)

The tiger mosquito has a white line on its head and thorax. Conversely, the yellow fever mosquito has a white line on its head and 4 white lines on its thorax, forming a lyre-shaped pattern.

\\n\\n

Illustrations: J.Luis Ordóñez, CREAF (CC-BY-NC 3.0). Right photo: James Gathany (ECDC, public domain)

The tiger mosquito and the yellow fever mosquito have white lines and spots on the abdomen, but those of the tiger mosquito are thinner than those of the yellow fever mosquito.

\\n\\n

Illustrations: J.Luis Ordóñez, CREAF (CC-BY-NC 3.0)
Is this a storm drain or sewer?
Is it in a public area?
Does it contain stagnant water and/or mosquito larvae?
Has stagnant water, but with no larvae
Have you seen mosquitoes nearby (<10 meters)?

Storm drains and sewers are the most productive breeding sites for the tiger mosquito and the yellow fever mosquito because they accumulate stagnant water inside. These mosquitoes do not breed on beaches or in rivers, lakes, ponds, or wetlands.

\\u0020\\u0020\\u0020\\u0020\\u0020\\u0020\\u0020\\n

A number of these images have been donated by the Barcelona Public Health Agency.
Public areas are those with free access to the public, like roads, squares, parks, and green spaces. They do not include private lots or other private properties.
In order to survive, mosquito larvae need stagnant and turbid water available for several days before they become adult mosquitoes.

The tiger mosquito and the yellow fever mosquito do not normally travel far from their breeding site - usually no more than 500 meters. Therefore, adults are often found near their breeding sites.\\n\\n\\u0020\\u0020\\u0020\\u0020
Zoom in with fingers to expand the image view.
There is no internet connection. Connect the device to the network to continue validating.
Error connecting with picture validation server.
Check this short guide before starting using the app
Take a photo if you see a breeding site on a public space.
Send photos of tiger mosquito or fever yellow mosquito
Take a good photo and show all the body parts of the mosquito.
Consult your sent reports and validate photos from other participants
See your record participation and learn to validate photos of tiger mosquitos.
You will receive news and notifications from experts about your sent data.
Send good photos and validate photos from other participants to get a higher level.
Configure the app from the menu, go to extra content and adjust the settings.

If you want, you can login to save your sightings and score, so that you will be able to synchronize different devices as well as to retrieve your data if you have uninstalled the app. More information on the settings and privacy policy.
You will find more information and tips to take good photos at:\nwww.mosquitoalert.com

Logging in using one of these accounts will enable you to save your data and points, retrieve them via another device (if you lose or change your mobile or uninstall the app), and participate via different devices simultaneously. If you prefer not to log in, you can continue anonymously. 

Mosquito Alert never receives personal information when you log in using an external account. All participants are anonymous as far as Mosquito Alert is concerned. 

See our privacy policy for more information.
